vjdbv1.0_description: Genbank title of the sequence.
City where the sample the sequence originates from was collected or sampled.
The level of the sequence completeness compare to the representative sequence in refseq in percentage
State/Region where the sample the sequence originates from was collected/sampled.
vjdbv1.0_notes: This is defined different from the duplicate below. Meaning for submission Tool was to have a geographical level higher than countries (continents). We keep it (mostly redundant), might be useful for later curation;

vjdbv1.0_description: ENA analysis object Accession.
Name of the institution/affiliation to which the person collecting the sample belongs
vjdbv1.0_notes: conform with submitter organization; not sure

vjdbv1.0_description: Health state of the host at the time of sample collection, e.g. diseased or healthy
The geographic location by latitude, where the sample the sequence originates from was collected/sampled. (DD)
The geographic location by longitude, where the sample the sequence originates from was collected/sampled. (DD)
Continent where the sample the sequence originates from was collected/sampled.
vjdbv1.0_notes: Region unclear -> Check again where it came from, recheck naming and vocabulary, INSDC country list contains the oceans; Name suggestions macroregion or georegion; no direct source but constructable (group countries into clusters);

vjdbv1.0_description: Describes the physical, environmental or local geographical source of the sample, e.g. soil
vjdbv1.0_notes: as it is, for revision with data; not sure

vjdbv1.0_description: Name of the person that collected the sample
The cuttoff used to determine if the sample is seropositive.
References an ENA assembly to an ENA Experiment.
Natural behaviour of the sampled host.
The hosts main disease diagnosis.
The hosts disease outcome. Did the host recover from the disease?

The symptoms that have been reported in relation to the illness, such as cough, diarrhea, fever, headache, malaise, myalgia, nausea, runny_nose, shortness_of_breath, sore_throat. If multiple exposures are applicable, please state them separated by semicolon.
Natural habitat of the avian or mammalian host
The unique ID of the sampled host from the BV-BRC.
Method used to assess if a sample is flu positive/negative. Multiple methods are seperated by semicolon(s).
Result of the given methods. Positive(P) or Negative(N). For multiple test the results are delimited by semicolon, e.g. P; P.
Influenza virus type classification: A, B or C.
The test result for other tested pathogens given as described by influenza test result.
Was the sample tested for other pathogens? Insert the pathogenic organisms using semicolon as a delimiter, e.g. Newcastle. “None” is also valid.
Pangolin version used to determine the lineage.
If the sample was only received and not collected provide the receipt date.
RKI Accession of the virus sequence.
References a ENA assembly to an ENA Run object.
Serological variety of a species characterised by its antigenic properties, e.g. H1N1.
vjdbv1.0_notes: NCBI Virus has genotype, which includes Serotype, otherwise we have no valid informational source -> internal for now;

vjdbv1.0_description: Common abbreviations of the virus species name.
Temporary NCBI Tax ID used for mapping the taxonomy tree to the metadata table.
vjdbv1.0_notes: No mapping, seems to  be NCBI Tax ID; not sure

vjdbv1.0_description: Generic name of the sequence (Name of the entry).
The DOI of the publication associated with the sequence.
The PubMed ID of publication associated with the sequence.
vjdbv1.0_notes: needs curation before public; no example needed

vjdbv1.0_description: Last update date of the sequence in BVBRC (whole entry).
vjdbv1.0_changes: update definition: last update date of the record in bvbrc)

vjdbv1.0_description: Insert size for paired reads.
Instrument model used for sequencing.
The protocol used to construct the sequencing library.
The design of the sequencing library including details of how it was constructed.
The sequencing library layout specifies whether to expect single or paired configuration of reads.
The name for the sequencing library if any.
The method used to select for or against, enrich, or screen the material being sequenced.
The library source specifies the type of source material that is being sequenced.
The sequencing technique intended for this sequencing library.
Unique ID given by the investigator as strain might not be unique.
Antiviral treatment used for this subject, such as zanamavir oseltamivir, amantadine.
Dosage of the treatment taken by the subject. example: 0.05 mg.
Duration of antiviral treatment after onset of clinical symptoms in days.example: 5.
Initiation of antiviral treatment after onset of clinical symptoms in days. example: 2.5.
Whether or not the subject is gravid. if so, report date due or date post-conception and specify which of these two dates is being reported.
Was the subject confined to a hospital as a result of virus infection or problems occurring secondary to virus infection?
Other descriptive information relating to the host.
The number of days the illness lasted. example: 4
Date the subject showed an onset of symptoms. format: yyyy-mm-dd. example: 2011-10-20

The symptoms that have been reported in relation to the illness, such as cough, diarrhea, fever, headache, malaise, myalgia, nausea, runny_nose, shortness_of_breath, sore_throat. if multiple exposures are applicable, please state them separated by semicolon.
vjdb_example: fever; headache; malaise; myalgia; nausea; runny_nose

vjdbv1.0_description: Unique number of the strain which is reported as a part of the influenza strain name, such as a/chicken/fujian/411/2002(hxn1). format: integer number, example: 411
Date that the influenza vaccination was administered to the subject over the past year. format: yyyy-mm-dd. example: 2007-05-12
Influenza vaccinations that have been administered to the subject over the last year. example: 2009 h1n1 flumist

vjdbv1.0_name: Influenza-like Illness at the Time of Sample Collection
vjdbv1.0_description: Is the subject at the time of sample collection considered to have influenza like illness?
Dose used for the inoculoation experiment.
Brief description of the protocol inoculation route.
Is the virus stock used for the inoculation available?
Does the h1n1 influenza virus originate from a swine-like outbreak (as opposed to a seasonal flu)?
Description helping to explain what the cut off value means.
Number of host individuals inoculated for the experiment.
Use of personal protective equipment, such as gloves, gowns, during any type of exposure. example: mask
Reason for the sample collection.
vjdb_example: active surveillance in response to outbreak; market sample

vjdbv1.0_description: Conditions at which sample was stored, usually storage temperature, duration and location. in soil context: explain how and for how long the soil sample was stored before dna extraction (fresh/frozen/other).
Free-form text describing the sample, its origin, and its method of isolation.
Designation of information related to vaccination history as self reported or documented.
Briefly describes the goals, purpose, and scope of the study.  this need not be listed if it can be inherited from a referenced publication.
Exposure of the subject to infected human or animals, such as poultry, wild bird or swine. If multiple exposures are applicable, these are separated by semicolon. Example: poultry;wild bird

Duration of the exposure of the subject to an infected human or animal. If multiple exposures are applicable, their duration is stated in the same order in which the exposure in the field was reported: 'subject exposure'. Example: 1 day; 0.33 days (Units: year)
Clear and useful title of the study/project, e.g. a title usable for a publication or the purpose of the project and its timeframe.
Clear and useful title to identify the sequencing experiment. This title will not be submitted to the ENA on submission.
Clear and useful title to identify the sample the sequence originates from was collected/sampled. This title will not be submitted to the ENA on submission.

Setting within which the subject is exposed to animals, such as farm, slaughterhouse, food preparation. if multiple exposures are applicable, please state their type in the same order in which you reported the exposure in the field 'subject exposure'. example: backyard flock; confined animal feeding operation
vjdb_example: backyard flock; confined animal feeding operation

vjdbv1.0_description: Dosage of the vaccine taken by the host. example: 0.05 ml
Lot number of the vaccine.
Manufacturer of the vaccine.

vjdbv1.0_name: WHO/OIE/FAO Clade (Required for HPAI H5N1 Viruses)
vjdbv1.0_description: WHO/OIE/FAO clade should be included for highly pathogenic h5n1 viruses. example: 2.2
Collection of outdated names for a particular virus.
Byte range data of the sample in the sequence file without the header
The file location of the multiseq fasta file including the parent folder name
Date of the insertion into the VirJen database
The last date the metadata was updated in the VirJen database.
A 'Subrealm' is a rank in the taxonomic hierarchy into which virus species can be classified. Defined by the ICTV.
A 'Subkingdom' is a rank in the taxonomic hierarchy into which virus species can be classified. Defined by the ICTV.
A 'Subclass' is a rank in the taxonomic hierarchy into which virus species can be classified. Defined by the ICTV.
A 'Subrealm' is a rank in the taxonomic hierarchy into which virus species can be classified. Defined by the NCBI.
A 'Subkingdom' is a rank in the taxonomic hierarchy into which virus species can be classified. Defined by the NCBI.
A 'Subclass' is a rank in the taxonomic hierarchy into which virus species can be classified. Defined by the NCBI.
Host Ages in a uniform unit, TBD
vjdbv1.0_notes: Use for sorting by host age, and relevant for plotting; not sure

vjdbv1.0_description: Indicator that sequences came from samples from a laboratory setting, and not from a wild host.
There is one page in Viralzone associated to this Taxon ID.
ICTV ID from Master_Species_List file
Commonly used virus name (or names separated by a semi-colon).
Hash ontent for the rank in the taxonomy tree.
A flag that indicates if the record is the latest update in VirJenDB database
List of VirJenDB metadata fields and their content when they are updated in each release in compare to the previous version
Virus genome sequence
VIrus genome sequence hash SHA256
The program used for host genome assembly.
phage id internal identifier
vjdbv1.0_notes: From Malte's dataset, deprecated (VirJenDB Accession as new Identifier), soon to be removed

vjdbv1.0_description: The list of the hash for the lineage of the rank in the ICTV VMR.
Taxonomy Table Hash ID of the Parent Rank
Taxonomy Table Hash ID of the Rank
ICTV Rank Name
ICTV Rank Type
IMGVR UVIG ID
True if the current virus sequence is a coding strand. Calculated by part of the ViralClust tool suite. Only intended for ssRNA viruses.

Confidence score associated with the method by which "Host Accession ID" from NCBI GenBank or or "NCBI Taxonomy Lineage" was associated to the virus sequence. Multiple host associations/predictions separated by semicolons.

Length of the sequence as calculated by CheckV v1.0.1 against the default CheckV database v1.5. For more information about CheckV please see the tool page at: https://bitbucket.org/berkeleylab/checkv/src/master

Prediction of whether the sequence is a provirus by CheckV v1.0.1 against the default CheckV database v1.5. For more information about CheckV please see the tool page at: https://bitbucket.org/berkeleylab/checkv/src/master

If the sequence is predicated as a provirus, the length ofthe provirus, calculated by CheckV v1.0.1 against the default CheckV database v1.5. For more information about CheckV please see the tool page at: https://bitbucket.org/berkeleylab/checkv/src/master

The number of genes in the virus sequence as calculated by CheckV v1.0.1 against the default CheckV database v1.5. For more information about CheckV please see the tool page at: https://bitbucket.org/berkeleylab/checkv/src/master

The number of virus genes in the virus sequence as calculated by CheckV v1.0.1 against the default CheckV database v1.5. For more information about CheckV please see the tool page at: https://bitbucket.org/berkeleylab/checkv/src/master

The number of host genes as calculated by CheckV v1.0.1 against the default CheckV database v1.5. For more information about CheckV please see the tool page at: https://bitbucket.org/berkeleylab/checkv/src/master

Quality tier of the virus genome as noted by CheckV v1.0.1 against the default CheckV database v1.5. For more information about CheckV please see the tool page at: https://bitbucket.org/berkeleylab/checkv/src/master 
Possible values:
Complete
High-quality (>90% completeness)
Medium-quality (50-90% completeness)
Low-quality (<50% completeness)
Undetermined quality
MIUVIG quality as noted by CheckV v1.0.1 against the default CheckV database v1.5. For more information about CheckV please see the tool page at: https://bitbucket.org/berkeleylab/checkv/src/master

Completeness of the virus genome sequenceas calculated by CheckV v1.0.1 against the default CheckV database v1.5. For more information about CheckV please see the tool page at: https://bitbucket.org/berkeleylab/checkv/src/master

Method of determining the completeness of the virus genome sequence as calculated by CheckV v1.0.1 against the default CheckV database v1.5. For more information about CheckV please see the tool page at: https://bitbucket.org/berkeleylab/checkv/src/master

Amount of virus genome sequence contamination as calculated by CheckV v1.0.1 against the default CheckV database v1.5. For more information about CheckV please see the tool page at: https://bitbucket.org/berkeleylab/checkv/src/master

Number of times the virus genome was found in the as calculated by CheckV v1.0.1 against the default CheckV database v1.5. For more information about CheckV please see the tool page at: https://bitbucket.org/berkeleylab/checkv/src/master

Warnings generated by running CheckV v1.0.1 against the default CheckV database v1.5. For more information about CheckV please see the tool page at: https://bitbucket.org/berkeleylab/checkv/src/master
Percentage of Ns within the whole sequence from BVBRC.

vjdbv1.0_description: Number of contigs in the sequence.
Version of the sequence (whole entry).
Why was the collected sample sequenced?
The level of the Assembly (contig, scaffold, chromosome, complete genome).

vjdbv1.0_description: Minimum length of consecutive Ns to be considered a gap.
The program used for genome assembly.
Identifier on how to treat the submitted assembly. Currently only assemblies from ‘clone or isolate’ are permitted.

vjdbv1.0_description: BVBRC Lab Host, common name of the lab host.

vjdbv1.0_description: The NCBI Taxonomy ID of the lab host.
The scientific species name of the lab host.
The run data file model.
The name or relative pathname of a run data file.
Host age given by a number. Is connected to Host Age Unit. The number should match the unit. E.g. 2 years
Unit that describes the host age. Is connected to Host Age. Should fit the number, e.g. 2 years

vjdbv1.0_description: Clear and useful title to identify the analysis of your sequencing experiment. This title will not be submitted to the ENA on submission.
GenBank Accession of the virus sequence. It equals NCBI Accession, ENA Accession, and DDBJ Accession, which are part of the INSDC.
NCBI Assembly Accession of the virus sequence.

References the BioSample Accession that the virus sequence is a part of (INSDC).
Date when the sample the virus sequence originates from was collected or sampled.

vjdbv1.0_description: Country or sea area where the sample the virus sequence originates from was collected or sampled.
Determines if this virus sequence is available in Genbank.
Determines if this virus sequence is a reference sequence in the RefSeq database.
Country name and additional identifier like a state abbreviation from where the sample the sequence originates from was collected/sampled.
Common name of the host the virus sequence was collected from, e.g. human. Currently (v1.0) no ontology is applied.

vjdbv1.0_description: Country of the submitter's organization.
Region or location of the organization of the submitters.
Unique identifier of the virus sequence, assigned by VirJenDB.
Version of the virus sequence record, including metadata, assigned by VirJenDB.
Name of the virus strain associated with the sample from which the virus sequence was obtained.
A 'Realm' is the highest taxonomic rank into which a virus sequence can be classified. Defined by the ICTV.
A 'Kingdom' is a rank in the taxonomic hierarchy into which a virus sequence can be classified. Defined by the ICTV.
A 'Phylum' is a rank in the taxonomic hierarchy into which a virus sequence can be classified. Defined by the ICTV.
A 'Subphylum' is a rank in the taxonomic hierarchy into which a virus sequence can be classified. Defined by the ICTV.
A 'Class' is a rank in the taxonomic hierarchy into which a virus sequence can be classified. Defined by the ICTV.
A 'Order' is a rank in the taxonomic hierarchy into which a virus sequence can be classified. Defined by the ICTV.
A 'suborder' is a rank in the taxonomic hierarchy into which a virus sequence can be classified. Defined by the ICTV.
A 'Family' is a rank in the taxonomic hierarchy into which a virus sequence can be classified. Defined by the ICTV.
A 'Subfamily' is a rank in the taxonomic hierarchy into which a virus sequence can be classified. Defined by the ICTV.
A 'Genus' is a rank in the taxonomic hierarchy into which a virus sequence can be classified. Defined by the ICTV.
A 'Subgenus' is a rank in the taxonomic hierarchy into which a virus sequence can be classified. Defined by the ICTV.

A Species is the lowest taxonomic rank in the hierarchy approved by the ICTV. While subspecies levels of classification may exist for some viruses (e.g. Hepatitis C virus), the ICTV does not classify viruses below the species level. Defined by the ICTV.
A 'Realm' is the highest taxonomic rank into which virus species can be classified. Defined by the NCBI.
A 'Kingdom' is a rank in the taxonomic hierarchy into which a virus sequence can be classified. Defined by the NCBI.
A 'Phylum' is a rank in the taxonomic hierarchy into which a virus sequence can be classified. Defined by the NCBI.
A 'Subphylum' is a rank in the taxonomic hierarchy into which a virus sequence can be classified. Defined by the NCBI.
A 'Class' is a rank in the taxonomic hierarchy into which a virus sequence can be classified. Defined by the NCBI.
A 'Order' is a rank in the taxonomic hierarchy into which a virus sequence can be classified. Defined by the NCBI.
A 'suborder' is a rank in the taxonomic hierarchy into which a virus sequence can be classified. Defined by the NCBI.
A 'Family' is a rank in the taxonomic hierarchy into which a virus sequence can be classified. Defined by the NCBI.
A 'Subfamily' is a rank in the taxonomic hierarchy into which a virus sequence can be classified. Defined by the NCBI.
A 'Genus' is a rank in the taxonomic hierarchy into which virus a sequence can be classified. Defined by the NCBI.
A 'Subgenus' is a rank in the taxonomic hierarchy into which a virus sequence can be classified. Defined by the NCBI.

A Species is the lowest taxonomic rank in the hierarchy approved by the NCBI. While subspecies levels of classification may exist for some viruses (e.g. Hepatitis C virus), the NCBI does not classify viruses below the species level. Defined by the NCBI.
vjdbv1.0_notes: NCBI Virus has only the virus species in this field, Taxonomy Descision; no example needed

vjdbv1.0_description: References the Host GTDB Species Name to which the NCBI host taxonomy ID of the virus sequence could be mapped. See the mapping file on the Datasets page.
Flag indicating yes if the sequence is a representative for a group of identical VirJenDB sequences.
The VirJenDB ID for the unique representative sequence. For the non-phages, the smallest Accession in the group. See documentation for selection details.
Flag indicating yes if the sequence is a representative sequence of a group of sequences, computed by VClust. See documentation for selection details.
The VirJenDB ID of the representative of its cluster. See documentation for selection details.
The tool used to predict the virus sequence. No value means that it is not a predicted virus sequence.
Host Accession from NCBI GenBank that refers to the host sequence from which the prophage was predicted.
References the BioProject Accession associated with the host sequence.
References the BioSample Accession associated with the host sequence.
Country or sea area origin of the sample from which the host sequence originates.
Date of collection of the sample from which the host sequence originates.
Associated Host IMGM Taxon OID from which the virus sequence was extracted by IMG/VR.
Average sequencing depth across the host sequence. Multiple host associations/predictions separated by semicolons.
Instrument or sequencing platform used for host sequencing. Multiple host associations/predictions separated by semicolons.

Method by which the fields "Host Accession ID" from NCBI GenBank or "NCBI Taxonomy Lineage" was associated to the virus sequence. Currently (v1.0) either a host association from the data source or PhiSpy prophage prediction. Multiple host associations/predictions separated by semicolons.
Sub-species designation of the virus sequence, from NCBI GenBank field "clade".
Sub-species designation of the virus sequence, from NCBI GenBank field "genotype".
Sub-species designation of the virus sequence, from NCBI GenBank field "serotype".
Sub-species designation of the virus sequence, from NCBI GenBank field "isolate".
